text: I hadn’t seen a discussion about a forum - is a web forum in addition to chat (slack/zulip/discourse) an option? Even if its something as simple as a FoC subreddit

text: the problem with forums and subreddit is that many small messages that turn into interesting conversations won't be shared because it feels they are too small for a topic or too much problem creating a new topic for a small comment

elements.text: the problem with forums and subreddit is that many small messages that turn into interesting conversations won't be shared because it feels they are too small for a topic or too much problem creating a new topic for a small comment

text: The thing I like about forums/reddits is that it’s way easier for multiple different threads of conversation to go on based on a shared link - I haven’t seen zulip/discourse before, but Slack for example, if there are more than two conversations going on in a thread it is hard to follow who different people are responding to or catch up if you’ve missed the beginning

text: what’s the verdict btw on moving off Slack potentially? I was reminded of the pain point of Slack community again when I posted this link in general (<https://github.com/microsoft/verona>) but I wanted to actually first search to see if it was already submitted (but then I remembered we had limited Slack history). This got me thinking about one potential principle we may want to consider for any community tool … to what degree does it support the emergence of structure nd almost wiki-like archiving? Just a stray thought

attachments.fallback:
[January 16th, 2020 7:00 PM] ivanreese: <!channel> I have drafted a short survey that I would like your feedback on / contributions to. This survey, after benefiting from your polish, will be shared in <#C5T9GPWFL|general> and mentioned on the upcoming episode of the podcast. I'll probably remind people about it a few times, and then close it after a few weeks. I intend to use the data from this survey, plus the numerous discussions from the past month, to answer the "Should we leave Slack?" question. The survey asks about more than just Slack, though, as I think it'd be helpful to know a bit more about the composition of the community in aggregate. The draft is on Github, and you can contribute to it with PRs, issues, <http://hypothes.is|hypothes.is> annotations (if you're crazy), or replies to this Slack message — I'll do the legwork of collecting it all. Thank you!

<https://github.com/ivanreese/foc-survey/blob/master/README.md>

text: I do think a bit about structure when comparing chat vs forums. As for wiki-like archiving, there's been talk in the past about setting up a community wiki. Someone actually did set one up, but it didn't stick. I think the community might be a bit too small to sustain multiple distinct efforts that require group input. For instance, not many folks are participating in the newsletter, even though it's very open for input.

elements.text: I do think a bit about structure when comparing chat vs forums. As for wiki-like archiving, there's been talk in the past about setting up a community wiki. Someone actually did set one up, but it didn't stick. I think the community might be a bit too small to sustain multiple distinct efforts that require group input. For instance, not many folks are participating in the newsletter, even though it's very open for input.

text: Still, no harm in trying things. Let me know if you'd like any questions added to the survey about these ideas you've raised.

text:
<@UN89MTTML> <@UBN9AFS0N> A handful of people have asked for us to move to _both_ a forum and a chat (whether Slack or Zulip or otherwise). They often couple that with the suggestion of finding some way to synchronize activity between them, some sort of bot or something. Nobody has actually gone past the ideating stage with that proposal, though — no proof of concept for what that synchronization would look/feel like. My concern with centering the community on two different platforms is that... we're already such a small community. This Slack can sometimes go for a few days without any activity. If we split the community across two platforms, I feel like one of them would quickly fizzle out and the people who preferred that one would not come back to rejoin the rest of the group.

There is already a Reddit group that is very, very closely aligned with this FoC slack — r/nosyntax. Rather than creating a FoC subreddit in addition to whatever chat or forum we settle on, perhaps we could just strike up some sort of official partnership with the mods of nosyntax, and cross promote each other. Then, rather than running a sync bot (which would surely be very noisy and people would just ignore it), folks who participate in both communities would cross-post any particularly interesting conversations.

elements.text: A handful of people have asked for us to move to
both

a forum and a chat (whether Slack or Zulip or otherwise). They often couple that with the suggestion of finding some way to synchronize activity between them, some sort of bot or something. Nobody has actually gone past the ideating stage with that proposal, though — no proof of concept for what that synchronization would look/feel like. My concern with centering the community on two different platforms is that... we're already such a small community. This Slack can sometimes go for a few days without any activity. If we split the community across two platforms, I feel like one of them would quickly fizzle out and the people who preferred that one would not come back to rejoin the rest of the group.

There is already a Reddit group that is very, very closely aligned with this FoC slack — r/nosyntax. Rather than creating a FoC subreddit in addition to whatever chat or forum we settle on, perhaps we could just strike up some sort of official partnership with the mods of nosyntax, and cross promote each other. Then, rather than running a sync bot (which would surely be very noisy and people would just ignore it), folks who participate in both communities would cross-post any particularly interesting conversations.

text: I would suggest also taking the time to gather a little more demographic data, especially on professional roles. Not sure if professional sponsorship for the community is/will possibly be a goal, but being able to say “We have X% researchers, Y% compiler engineers, Z% founders, etc.” is useful both to know your community as well as to get sponsorships / deals.

text: I'm probably in the minority, but could we use something else than GitHub? A Google Forms based survey (or any other service with a GUI) would immediately prompt users to answer the questions and help you gather all the information.

text: The final survey will be a google form. As Nick said, this is just a draft for community review. I'm trying to do _everything_ out in the open with lots of collaboration, so that folks feel like the things I do are being decided by the community, not by me.

text:
Cool — I like the "blaggregator" idea quite a bit. After that survey is done and people have had a chance to respond, and after we've made whatever changes we're going to make to the community platform, I'm planning to spend some time adding additional tools like these ones you've found, and improving the documentation and first-run experience for people coming to the community. I think with a bit of work, we can make this community more engaging, more like a hub connecting all our efforts and projects, without making it too noisy for people who just want to casually follow along.

Thanks for the suggestions and taking the time to look up these tools!

elements.text:
Cool — I like the "blaggregator" idea quite a bit. After that survey is done and people have had a chance to respond, and after we've made whatever changes we're going to make to the community platform, I'm planning to spend some time adding additional tools like these ones you've found, and improving the documentation and first-run experience for people coming to the community. I think with a bit of work, we can make this community more engaging, more like a hub connecting all our efforts and projects, without making it too noisy for people who just want to casually follow along.

Thanks for the suggestions and taking the time to look up these tools!
